column2: Guide to Quality Childcare in Tameside

column1: A Parents' Guide to Childcare in Tameside
Choosing the right childcare for your child is an important step. In Tameside there is a wealth of options from which you can choose the right setting for your child.
But how do you know what's what? Where will you find the right advice to guide and help you in making the right choice for your child and you?
This page explains the different types of settings available for your child, the financial help you can be given, and the checklists you should go through before choosing your childcare setting.

There's also a section containing contact numbers for leading childcare agencies. It explains what they do and how they can help parents and their children make the most of the childcare provision available.
Good childcare can play a major part in helping the development of your child as well as providing you with the freedom you want to fulfil your own needs.

Hundreds of parents/carers place their children in suitable childcare settings every year with the help of guidance, information and advice from appropriate sources and agencies. In this pack, we’ve included the views of local parents who have used childcare settings in Tameside. We hope that you will gain from their experiences and knowledge.
There are five key types of setting in which you can place your child.
The setting you choose will depend on a number of key factors including:
• The number of hours you require your child to be looked after
• The financial help to which you may be entitled

When choosing the right childcare setting for your child you will, naturally, need to know that they will be happy and safe. Below is a 10-step checklist that you should run through when making your choice.
• Decide which daycare meets the needs of you and your child
• Always check that the daycare facility or childminder is registered with Ofsted, and has valid public liability insurance.
• Take your time before you decide to start your child. Visit, look around, feel the atmosphere - do you feel comfortable?
• Are you and your child made welcome?
• Do other children there look happy and well cared for?
• Go more than once - ask questions.
• Discuss your child's needs and your needs.
• Always agree a contract. Have a copy of the agreement for yourself.
• Find out about the facility, its day-to-day activities, hygiene and safety, meals and snacks, holidays and how much it will cost.
• Contact Tameside Children's Information Service for any further assistance or advice - 0161 342 5434.
What is a Private Day Nursery?

Day Nurseries are registered childcare facilities that offer full and part time childcare for children from 0 - 5 years. They are usually open all year round, with opening and closing times set to accommodate both working and non-working parents with children under 5. They are required to register with Ofsted to meet the 14 National Standards and must have public liability insurance. The majority of private day nurseries are also registered with Ofsted to provide free nursery education.
What do children do at a Private Day Nursery?

Planned activities and learning experiences will enhance every aspect of a child's development. They provide children with pre-school experiences such as art, craft and construction activities, sand and water play, adventure play, music and movement, books and stories etc., as well as the opportunity to socialise with other children. They provide a stable, secure and relaxed environment where parents and carers feel satisfied to leave their children.
What is the cost of a Private Day Nursery?

A full day can cost between £19 - £25. Part time places are also available as well as funded places for 3 and 4-year-olds receiving Nursery Education Grant. Working parents may be entitled to financial assistance if they are in receipt of Working Tax Credit - see financial assistance section.
How do I find a Private Day Nursery?
Ask friends/colleagues if they have used a group and were happy with it. Contact the Children's Information Service on 0161 342 5434 for a list of groups in your area.

'Going straight to school can be daunting for a four-year-old but if they've been in a setting like this it can help them make the move. My daughter is very independent and confident and much of that is down to attending a private day nursery' - Simone Rusholme
Still not found what you are looking for? Try our Search or our A to Z of Services:
